Posts.Title: what to say - - Christmas Letter lynne248 lynne248

Posts.Content: lynne248 wrote: sooo...it's not my Christmas letter, but my Grandfather's.  He does one every year and has a little update about each of his grandchildren.  He did put in last year's about me fighting cancer...and now he has asked what I would like to have put in this year's letter.  Nothing?  update?....  I have had some progression this year, had an ooph, changed meds up and am waiting for scans later this month to find where things are at.  But this is not the sort of thing I think people want to read in a Christmas letter. Recommendations? Dx 3/1/2010, 6cm+, Stage IV, 3/21 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Tykerb Face! lynne248 CoolBreeze

Posts.Content: lynne248 wrote: OK. I know I have a lot to be thankful for, and really?  A couple of zits?  I am worried about zits? You would think the diarrhea and dry skin would be what bothers me.  Nope. With an oopherectomy behind me and faslodex taking care of any other hormones, how is it even possible that zits appear? Another stage IVer, from a support group I'm in, said that some pink cream with vitamin E from the Body Shop worked wonders for her (said she got it from the Anti Cancer book).  Any one else have recommendations? Dx 3/1/2010, 6cm+, Stage IV, 3/21 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Tykerb Face! lynne248 CoolBreeze

Posts.Content: lynne248 wrote: OK.  I did what I know I'm not supposed to do and googled "stage IV breast cancer"...and found this: http://www.breastcancersociety.org/aboutbreastcancer/survivingbreastcancer/breastcancersurvival.shtml Specifically - - "... With the exception of some hard-to-detect types of breast cancer, few women who consciously look for the early warning signs of breast cancer will ever reach stage IV..."  I actually e-mailed them.  Something I rarely do.  Soooo angry at this. This is part of what I wrote: I did self examinations and had mammograms, despite being under 40...and yet I was diagnosed with stage IV breast cancer.  I believe you are trying to make people feel safe and encourage "conscious" effort to look for early warning signs of breast cancer, but you make it sound as if people who are diagnosed with stage IV (with the exception of some hard-to-detect types) are at fault.  If only they had been a little more "CONSCIOUS".  MADDENING.  Really.  Blame the victim.  That always works. I would very much appreciate a response from you on this matter. Dx 3/1/2010, 6cm+, Stage IV, 3/21 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: This kind of thing drives me crazy. lynne248 pbandj

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2011 07:30AM lynne248 wrote: OK.  Got a response (see below).  Not perfect, but better than nothing. (read from bottom up; it start's with an internal e-mail that forwarded my original e-mail.  And ends with my reply to them) - - - - - Thank you. Additionally, you should put in place a review process for content review before publishing items on your website.  If you are to be a source for information than ensure that it is correct and helpful. Lynne From: James@breastcancersociety.org To: kristina@breastcancersociety.org CC: xxxxx@hotmail.com; laura@breastcancersociety.org Subject: RE: Stage IV breast cancer Date: Wed, 9 Nov 2011 11:30:27 -0700 Ms. XXXX makes an excellent point.  I believe this was an article placed on our site that was written with good intentions (by one of our data gatherers) but perhaps not with full respect to all situations, such as that of Ms. XXXXX and others in her situation.  Let's remove or re-word the portion of the article in question; Specifically: "... With the exception of some hard-to-detect types of breast cancer, few women who consciously look for the early warning signs of breast cancer will ever reach stage IV..." I think we all agree with Ms. XXXX's perspective in this and our hearts and concerns are fully with her. Kindest regards, James T. Reynolds II President / CEO Ph:  480-284-4014 Fax:  480-659-9807 Web:  www.BreastCancerSociety.org - - - - - From:Kristina Hixson [mailto:kristina@breastcancersociety.org] Sent: Wednesday, November 09, 2011 9:53 AM To: 'The Breast Cancer Society, Inc.' Subject:FW: Stage IV breast cancer Importance: High Please help me with a response here...I don't know enough medically to speak intelligently.  Should I forward to Chris Lee? - - - - - From:Laura Wallace [mailto:laura@breastcancersociety.org] Sent: Tuesday, November 08, 2011 4:20 PM To:kristina@breastcancersociety.org Subject:FW: Stage IV breast cancer Let's get this clarified ASAP!! Sincerely,    Laura Wallace Program Services Director    The Breast Cancer Society phone: 480-284-4014 ext. 102 fax: 480-718-7428 http://www.breastcancersociety.org/
Posts.Title: This kind of thing drives me crazy. lynne248 pbandj

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2012 05:35AM - edited Mar 25, 2012 09:48AM by lynne248 Hello kebab - - Sorry that you are joining us. Just wanted to let you know that I too am Canadian, married an American and moved to the US.  PM me if you have immigration questions, I might be able to help.  But as ibcmets said, make sure you can get medical coverage before coming down.  Even with coverage it's a bit of a shock getting medical bills in the mail. You should apply for CPP disability (both for you and your kids) before moving, you would still be eligible to apply after moving but your kids (from what I understand) would not be.
Posts.Title: Introducing myself kebab RavenMc

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2012 05:51PM lynne248 wrote: Hi Kay - - Not sure if I can help you too much.  I had an oopherectomy a little over a year ago (at age 35, almost 36).  Prior to the ooph, I was on the ovarian suppression drug (mine was a monthly shot), and prior to that I had had chemo - - which had put me into menopause.  To be honest, I didn't notice too much of a difference.  I had been having hot flashes before, and they got a little worse, but not too bad.  Initially I didn't want to have the operation.  Partially because I had just had a bunch of surgeries and I couldn't face another one, and largely because I had a difficult time acknowledging that I wouldn't be having another child. I'm happy I did do the ooph, being estrogen positive I knew that having another child was not something that I could do.  It wouldn't have been fair to my daughter or husband, or the new baby.  As much as I want another child, I know I can't.  It would be too selfish. The ooph lets me be on one less drug, and also allows for a little more freedom with the hubby!  ; )
Posts.Title: Oopherectomy? kayrnic Leah_S

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2012 11:25AM lynne248 wrote: Thanks all for the kind words and understanding. Coolbreeze - - we are doing a lot more than painting!  gutting the kitchen and one of the bathrooms, pulling up all of the carpet, painting everything!  Fun, yet also a stress point as my husband and I have to make a lot of decisions in the next month - - what contractor to go with, what finishes, colours, $$$$,... I feel a lot better today.  I've been lucky so far in that my side effects have been minimal, and I have been able to live and do, for the most part, how I want to.  I think some of the stress comes from the fact that new drugs could potentially mean new side effects.
Posts.Title: So hard not to think the worst lynne248 DivineMrsM

Posts.Content: lynne248 wrote: Just had my once-every-three-weeks apt with my oncologist (and my herceptin).  I pointed out to her some swelling and a lump I had found on my neck last week.  She did not look too happy about it, and promptly ordered CT, MRI and PET scans with a follow up visit next week. We are closing on our new house next week, my Dad is coming down for a visit, and I have to fit in all of the scans (during the day, since I have no veins left and they access my port and therefore need the proper people available), care for my 2 1/2 year old daughter and have the onc apt.  Ahhhhh!   It's so hard not to think that there has been rampant spread.  It's only been in my bones, other than my breasts, so far.  I'm keeping my fingers crossed but sometimes it's hard to stay positive.  I don't want to "dump" on friends or family until something is confirmed (or hopfully denied), so thanks for being here for me to rant to a little. Dx 3/1/2010, 6cm+, Stage IV, 3/21 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: So hard not to think the worst lynne248 DivineMrsM

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2013 04:46PM lynne248 wrote: Thanks all for the good advice and giving me a feeling that this will all be OK (or as OK as it gets for us). My itching has gotten a little better, I find keeping it moist helps a lot.  As for radiation, I have already had my chest wall and neck radiated, so that's a no go. Some how it all just feels a little bit better when you know others are/and have delt with what you are going through.  It's my favorite thing about this board.  The support and great advice.
Posts.Title: Anyone get skin mets? (looks and acts like IBC) lynne248 lynne248

Posts.Content: lynne248 wrote: Life is so weird.  I have just been thinking....really?  I have stage IV cancer?  really?  It seems unreal.  I had never been in the hospital before (other than for my daughter's birth) and now It's been almost 2 years since I was diagnosed (stage IV from the start).  Chemo, lumpectomy, mastectomy, radiation, mastectomy, oopherectomy, tamoxifen, steroids, herceptin, femera, ,...and endless scans. 2 years ago I was worried about going back to work and missing my baby.  Now, since I'm on LTD, I get to stay home with my 2 year old.  Just a weird trade off.   At 36, this wasn't anywhere on my radar.  I never would have thought I would be a stay at home mom with stage IV cancer.   Sorry for the ramble.  But I was up last night just thinking about all of this (and much more) and you guys are the only ones who would really get it.   Dx 3/1/2010, 6cm+, Stage IV, 3/21 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Just a ramble... lynne248 Padiddle

Posts.Content: lynne248 wrote: Hello all - - This has been a bad week. I have had a rash for a month or so (spread from a spot on my chest, to across my chest, then up to my neck and around the front of my neck). Thought it might be a reaction to afinitor, so took a week off of that, then we tried a couple of various drugs to clear it up, and when that didn't work, it was biopsied. Positive for cancer.  It's pretty much acting like inflammatory breast cancer (it's spreading through the lymphatic cells in the skin, as I understand it). So, my oncologist has moved me over to tdm-1 (had my first dose yesterday).  I'm having a hard time with this (the new area of cancer), as it's so visible and I can literally see it spread. Basically, I'm wondering if anyone else has a good news story to tell me about IBC/skin mets. Dx 3/1/2010, 6cm+, Stage IV, 3/21 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Anyone get skin mets? (looks and acts like IBC) lynne248 lynne248

Posts.Content: lynne248 wrote: My husband is wonderful.  He works full time, then comes home to an exhausted wife and energetic 2 year-old.  More often than not he cooks dinner and puts her to bed...and deals with bills and contractors (for renovations on our house).  I do what I can, but now that I have started a new round of chemo, I think what little I do is going to become even less.  We have great family that helps out the week of chemo, and lots of friends that have offered to help out as well. That all being said, I know that he is having a hard time with this.  We talk, but I know he needs an outside person to talk to.  He says that he has talked to friends, but like many on this board, have found that those friends pull away a little.  Probably due to being uncomfortable talking about such a depressing and crazy topic.  He did do the support group thing, but then someone lost their significant other and the group kind of fell apart (and he feels like he doesn't have the time to go, since we have so much going on). Who does your significant other talk to (besides yourself)? Dx 3/1/2010, 6cm+, Stage IV, 3/21 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Who does your significant other talk to about all this crap? lynne248 eric95us

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2012 09:31AM lynne248 wrote: thanks all for your advise/input/point of view.  I know he's being a "guy", but I hate that he has so much to go through.  I truly believe this is harder on some spouse's than on the person with cancer.
Posts.Title: Who does your significant other talk to about all this crap? lynne248 eric95us

Posts.Content: May 13, 2012 09:45PM lynne248 wrote: Just wanted to thank everyone for their advice. I made it through the party, only one person asked me "how are YOU doing"...turns out chasing a small child around a farm (it's where the party was at) is a good deterrent from people asking you about cancer.  ; ) Had a CT scan late last week and waiting on the  results.  This is one is a little scary, as I don't think the current drug combo is doing its duty.  I've done chemo, femara, tykerb, herceptin,...and I'm a little scared that next choice will be back to chemo again.  Oh well...it's only hair right?
Posts.Title: Freaking out a little - - Tykerb (and other) question lynne248 petjunkie

Posts.Content: lynne248 wrote: Back with my first chemo (TCH), I had neuropathy.  Some numbness to my feet.  It resolved itself shortly after chemo ended.  Now, I'm on Kadcyla, and have TRUE neuropathy.  Oh my lord.  Pins and needles on my toes, burning on the bottom of my feet, can't have blankets/sheets on my feet as it is painful/sensitive, stabbing pain comes and goes (just to keep it interesting),...  Wow.  I met with a naturpathic doctor, who specializes in oncology patients, and I am now on a few supplements.  She said it would get better after a week.  Hope I can make it through the week.  I'm starting to think some pain meds would be great, especially for sleep. Just needed to complain a little.  Dx 3/1/2010, 6cm+, Stage IV, 3/21 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Neuropathy. What new fresh hell is this? lynne248

Posts.Content: May 27, 2012 07:56AM lynne248 wrote: I'll just add mine to the list.  I too found mine when I was breast feeding my 8 month old daughter.  My OBGYN thought it was a blocked milk duct, but gave me a script for a mammogram if it didn't get better after a few days.  Mammogram, ultrasound and then biopsy.  Positive for cancer, why else would I be on this board? ; ). After reading all of these posts, I find it incredibly crazy how many of us were diagnosed when pregnant or shortly there after.  Such a happy time turned into such a scary and sad time.   Fingers crossed for your daughter and you.
Posts.Title: My daughter, 31, breastfeeding2 months postpartum has lump kayfh windy2011

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2012 01:43PM lynne248 wrote: I had never bought a new piece of furniture, that wasn't from IKEA.  Just got a chair and a half from Crate and Barrel that I wanted the first time I had chemo (over 2 years ago), but we didn't have a spot for it.  But we just moved into and renovated a house (actually still going through renos, but that is another story). I LOVE it!  We got the foot stool to go with it too.  I told my daughter it was "Mommy's toy box", for blankets.  She promptly put some her blankets in it. ...now if only we could buy a new couch, instead of this university age futon we have.
Posts.Title: I've never.... Mzmerz DivineMrsM

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2013 02:45PM lynne248 wrote: Thanks all for the advice.  The supplements weren't working (one of which was glucosamine)...so did Neurotin for a bit, which also didn't work, so now I'm on to Lyrica.  So hope this works.  I think I could handle the pain during the day (or so I say now), if only I could get a good nights sleep.  One thing that does seem to help a little, is putting ice packs on my feet.  Helps with that burning feeling.  I used to think I had a high pain tolerance, now I just feel like a wimp.  : )
Posts.Title: Neuropathy. What new fresh hell is this? lynne248

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2011 08:17PM lynne248 wrote: Such great responses.  Thank you everyone. I would say I'm somewhere in the middle.  My husband is wonderful, supportive, loving,...just plain great.  He has put up with my family and friends constantly coming to visit (we live in the US and I'm originally Canadian).  We are finally at a point where things are somewhat stable and I just don't want to burden him when not necessary.   But I did take the advice, and asked him how much he wants to hear.  Which is pretty much everything.  So that's what I will do.  He would love to be at all my appointments with me, but work and child don't allow for that.  We are about to start some counseling to help with talking about the future.  It's the one thing we don't talk about...and we really need to, especially when we have a small child to plan and care for.  PS - - I too actually enjoy my "alone" time during chemo/herceptin.  ; )
Posts.Title: How much do you share... lynne248 dianaleo

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2012 07:01AM lynne248 wrote: My daughter was 8 months when I was first diagnosed, almost 2 years ago.  I first worried and cried over her not remembering me, as well as not being able to see her grow up.  It's just so hard. One thing I have started to do is create a list of my girl friends and what they are strongest at (financial, education, fashion, relationships,...) all those things I hope I'm there to give advice to her for, but probably won't be able to,...and all those things she can't go to my husband for.  My plan is to talk to my friends, and then have a letter for my daughter telling her about this wonderful network of women (surrogate Mom's) that are there for her.  It makes me feel better to know that she will have this great group of women to go to and that will hopefully share with her some great stories about me too!  : ) No matter what it is difficult to think about her growing up without me.  It is the one thing that makes me cry at the drop of a hat.
Posts.Title: Coping as a young mom? rosasmommy klynnz

Posts.Content: lynne248 wrote: ...with your husband/signficant other/family? My hip/pelvis mets started to grow again a couple of months ago, so my onc changed my meds up (from tomoxifin to femara).  My hip seemed to stop hurting after a couple of weeks - - so fingers crossed we were hoping that that was the fix.   This week it started hurting again.  Pretty badly.  But I don't know if I should tell my husband yet.  I was thinking of waiting for the next set of scans (which would be in about 3 weeks).  He's already so stressed between work, our 2 year old and me (for the past year).  So basically, I was wondering how much everyone shares.  Everything?  Most?  Nothing?... Posts.Content: May 30, 2012 07:33PM lynne248 wrote: Well that just sucks!  I too had to donate both boobs to the cause, one at a time.  It was easier to get fitted for prosthetics though!  This way you can go flat, small, big...and change it up. It certainly changes the whole bedroom dynamic, but we have been able to work around it.   Not sure what you are doing about lymph nodes.  But for my 2nd mastectomy I didn't let them take any, as I didn't want to risk the possibility of lymphodima in both arms.  And what do they need the lymph nodes for anyway?  Staging?  ; ) Good luck and spoil yourself with something special.

Posts.Title: How much do you share... lynne248 dianaleo

Posts.Content: lynne248 wrote: OK - - So I had further progression about a month or so ago, and my Oncologist added Tykerb to the mix.  The progression is in the lymph nodes in my neck, so it's pretty easy to feel the lumps. I have been on Tykerb for about three weeks and met with my Oncologist yesterday.  She didn't see any improvement in the lymph nodes, and actually their might be a new one!  Sooo...we decided to give Tykerb another couple of weeks and then do another scan to check how things are doing.  Then she started talking about what medications we would move to next! I kind of had my heart set on sticking with Tykerb.  I was so hoping that the combo of Tykerb and Herceptin would do me for a few months (or preferably years).  It kind of scares me that I would be moving onto another set of drugs so quickly.   The drugs I have been doing for the last couple of years have allowed me to have a pretty great quality of life (other than exhaustion).  So a couple of questions: - those of you who were/are on Tykerb, how long before it was determined it was working/not working for you? - those of you with small children (under 5), how do you deal with side effects when trying to keep up with a bundle of energy, otherwise known as a small child? - Everyone. I'm at a low point right now, and about to go to a family reunion.  How do I make it through this weekend without breaking down in front of everyone?  Thanks to all. Dx 3/1/2010, 6cm+, Stage IV, 3/21 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Freaking out a little - - Tykerb (and other) question lynne248 petjunkie

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2011 01:16PM lynne248 wrote: Larcon -- I too was diagnosed stage IV, had a mastectomy, and then was diagnosed with cancer in the other breast.  I choose to have another mastectomy - - it was actually recommended by both my oncologist and surgeon.  One primary reason was because it had different tumor markers, so they said we should treat it as if it was a different cancer and since it had grown while on chemo and herceptin, that we should be aggressive in treatment.  I also got a 2nd opinion and they too agreed with getting a mastectomy.  The one difference in recommended treatment between my original team and the 2nd opinion was that the 2nd opinion team said there was no need to do a lymph node dissection.  My surgeon wanted to do one, but she did say that if any cancer was found in the auxiliary nodes that she would do a full resection.  I therefore choose not to touch the lymph nodes (hey, I'm already stage IV...who cares what the stage of the new cancer is) as I didn't want to have the risk of potential lymphodima in BOTH sides.   So far so good.  Are your markers the same?  Even if they are it could still be a new "primary" cancer.  I would recommend getting a 2nd opinion.  Good luck.
